 Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. 
‘THE BLACK PANTHERS: VINTAGE PRINTS BY STEPHEN SHAMES’ Toward the end of the civil rights movement Huey P. Newton and Bobby Seale founded the Black Panther Party in 1966 in Oakland, Calif. In hindsight the party had a fairly reasonable agenda for social change and the empowerment of African-Americans — employment, education, decent housing, social justice and political representation — but it was branded as a shadowy revolutionary organization and a threat to national security. This new exhibition commemorates the 40th anniversary of the founding of the Black Panther Party, bringing together almost 100 photographs of the group’s leaders, demonstrations and other activities from about 1967 to 1973 by Stephen Shames, the party’s unofficial official photographer. Most of the images are small black-and-white prints, but they have a disquieting, momentous presence. One especially powerful image, above, shows the militant posturing of a pair of Panther security guards (Glen Wheeler, left, and Claudia Grayson) outside a funeral for a slain party member at a church in Oakland in 1971. Mr. Shames photographed not only the public face of the movement but also private moments, including secret meetings of Panther leaders and their home life. Simple but thoughtful, the photographs humanize the group whose driving ambition was equality. (Through May 26, Steven Kasher Gallery, 521 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, 212-966-3978, stevenkasher.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO
Museums
★ AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM: MARTíN RAMíREZ,  through May 13. Ramírez, a Mexican peasant who immigrated to Northern California and died there at 68 in 1963, spent the last 32 years of his life in a mental hospital, making some of the greatest art of the last century. He had his own way with materials and color, and an unforgettable cast of characters (most notably, a mounted caballero and a levitating Madonna crowned like the Statue of Liberty). But most of all, Ramírez had his own brand of pictorial space, established by rhythmic systems of parallel lines, both curved and straight, whose mesmerizing expansions and contractions simultaneously cosset and isolate his figures. In addition to being one of the season’s best exhibitions and the first of his work in a New York museum, this show should render null and void the distinction between insider and outsider art. 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040, folkartmuseum.org. (Roberta Smith)★ AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY: ‘GOLD,’ through Aug. 19. Having delved into pearls, diamonds and amber, the museum applies its time-tested show-and-tell formula to the premier precious natural material, gold. This astounding array of art, artifacts and natural samples — larded with fascinating facts and tales — ranges from prehistoric times to the present. Stops along the way include pre-Columbian empires, sunken treasure, Bangladesh dowry rituals and the moon landing. It turns out that gold comes from the earth in forms as beautiful as anything man has thought to do with it, but that gold ingots have a brute force all their own. You are certain to emerge with mind boggled and eyes dazzled. Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, amnh.org. (Smith)★ ASIA SOCIETY: GLASS, GILDING, AND GRAND DESIGN: ART OF SASANIAN IRAN (224-642), through May 20. This glinting, glowing show is a reduction of a much larger Paris exhibition that included material from Iranian museums impossible to bring to the United States. With some 70 examples of silver, glass and silk textile fragments, many from European museums, this is still substantial and the first major exhibition of its kind in this part of the world for more than 30 years. For about four centuries, the Sasanians ruled territory stretching from present-day Iran and Iraq to North Africa. Their only rivals were Rome, Byzantium and, at the very end, the early Islamic dynasties. Much of their surviving art is a sterling example of empire in action. 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400, asiasociety.org. (Holland Cotter) ★ BROOKLYN MUSEUM: ‘GLOBAL FEMINISMS,’ through July 1. Too much of the work in this sprawling, international assembly of recent pieces by nearly 90 women from nearly 50 countries is body-oriented and doesn’t venture far beyond the essentialism of Judy Chicago’s indomitable 1975-79 installation opus, “The Dinner Party,” whose enshrinement in the new Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art this exhibition celebrates. Thoroughly dominated by photography and video, with a documentary slant to many of its better moments, the show is more about information, politics and the struggle for equality than it is about art in any very concentrated or satisfying sense. That doesn’t keep parts of it from being energetic and illuminating, especially as a record of the way that feminism has gripped and jump-started the imaginations of women around the world. 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Smith)
BROOKLYN MUSEUM: ‘KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,’ through July 29. This show of about 60 works by one of the greats of 19th-century American landscape painting has as its centerpiece “Kindred Spirits” (1849), a tribute to the landscapist Thomas Cole and his friend the poet-journalist William Cullen Bryant. A founder of the Hudson River School but one of its less dramatic painters, Durand (1796-1886) favored the realistic approach to landscape advocated by the English critic John Ruskin, rather than the metaphorical view held by Cole and other Hudson River artists that its representation ought to express God’s sublimity. Obeying Ruskin’s call for truth to nature, Durand explored forest interiors with close attention to the ways of trees, foliage and rocks, while his larger and more elaborate pictures are Arcadian visions suffused with light, color and atmospheric perspective. If the show reveals some of Durand’s weaknesses — repetitive themes and borrowings from other artists — it also reveals his potent role in shaping the aesthetic of 19th-century America. (See above.) 
(Grace Glueck)
★ CHELSEA ART MUSEUM: ‘DANGEROUS BEAUTY,’ through April 21. A somewhat timely update of a well-worn idea, this show of contemporary works in a variety of mediums by 18 artists examines the beauty myth in art, advertising and the fashion industry. Eloquent but blunt imagery of anorexic girls, chiseled male beefcake and close-ups of surgically deformed faces predominates, reminding us of the violent extremes to which some people will go in pursuit of society’s ideal of beauty and a designer body. The rest of the show — often pointing an accusatory finger at skinny models, cosmetic labels and the mass media — feels familiar in its critique, but the basic premise about the ideology of beauty in our culture is beyond argument. 556 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-0719, chelseaartmuseum.org. (Benjamin Genocchio)COOPER-HEWITT NATIONAL DESIGN MUSEUM: ‘DESIGN LIFE NOW: NATIONAL DESIGN TRIENNIAL 2006,’ through July 29. Like its two predecessors this ambitious show illuminates the volatile, contradictory and ever-expanding field of design, but fails to call it to order. The inclusions range from genius to schlock, delightful to dispiriting. They cover medical innovation, military hardware, completely frivolous reiterations of received ideas (far too many of which trace to Surrealism), sundry Web sites and magazines, haute couture, architecture and recycling — more varieties of recycling than you can easily count. The show coalesces into deliberately orchestrated skirmishes between conflicting principles and entities: corporate and private, decorative and essential. 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400, ndm.si.edu. (Smith) FRICK COLLECTION: ‘GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,’ through May 27. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org. (Glueck)
INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: ‘HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON’S SCRAPBOOK: PHOTOGRAPHS, 1932-46,’ through April 29. Arrived by way of the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson in Paris, this show has more than 300 of the prints the photographer glued into an album and toted to New York for curators at the Museum of Modern Art to cull. Captured by the Nazis, he had been presumed dead when the Modern planned his retrospective. Then he turned up alive — the “posthumous” exhibition opened, with him in attendance, in 1947. The current exhibition reconstructs as best as possible the layout of the scrapbook as Cartier-Bresson originally organized the pictures. It surveys the revolutionary work he shot in Spain, Italy, Mexico, Britain and France. His taste for uncanny detail linked him to Surrealism and Surrealist wit, but unlike many Surrealists, he remained committed to human values. Boys mug at his camera. Prostitutes swan. Their gazes equalize them with us. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, icp.org.
 (Michael Kimmelman)INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: ‘MARTIN MUNKACSI: THINK WHILE YOU SHOOT!’ through April 29. Munkacsi, who inspired Cartier-Bresson, was, by contrast, self-taught, a creature of his own devising. This is the most complete retrospective, with a thick catalog (not too well researched) and dozens of vintage prints from the 1920s through the early ’60s. He favored scenes of daily life, absorbing avant-garde ideas about odd angles and abstract compositions. His sports photographs epitomized his special gift for action and movement. Munkacsi was a stylist, and he made catchy images the only way he knew how, in a modernist mode. He became a celebrity in America. He photographed Fred Astaire dancing and Joan Crawford poolside. In the breezy layouts of Harper’s Bazaar, the work looked brilliant. (See above.) (Kimmelman) ★ JAPAN SOCIETY: ‘AWAKENINGS: ZEN FIGURE PAINTING IN MEDIEVAL JAPAN,’ through June 17. Japan Society has a history of producing exquisite shows of Buddhist art. And this one, with four dozen paintings of Buddhists gods and saints hung in shrinelike alcoves, is transporting. And it covers an unusually broad swath of geography, bringing together 13th- to 16th-century hanging scrolls not only from Japan but also from China, where Zen Buddhism, called Chan in Chinese, originated. 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155, japansociety.org. (Cotter)THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: ‘COAXING THE SPIRITS TO DANCE,’ through Dec. 2. How the Papuans practiced their beliefs on the remote Pacific island of New Guinea in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when they still had little contact with the West, is the complex and fascinating story told in this exhibition of some 60 objects and 30 rare photographs of the works on site or in actual use. The carved and painted “spirit boards” made throughout the gulf region, on the south coast of present-day Papua New Guinea, are probably the most easily recognized of the area’s traditional artworks. Their central designs, passed down from fathers to sons and through marriages, typically represent a bush or river spirit, with a heavily stylized face and perhaps a small body, surrounded by various totemic symbols. More daring in concept are the masks used in ritual dances. Papuan art may not be as varied or exciting as that of many African or Amerind peoples, but it records a vibrant community. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Glueck) * METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: ‘VENICE AND THE ISLAMIC WORLD, 828-1797,’ through July 8. At its peak in the Renaissance, Venice, the Most Serene, was a giant, clamorous Costco-on-the-Rialto. All the necessities, and most of the luxuries, of life flowed into and through it, with many items arriving from Islamic Africa and the Near East. With classic Met largesse, this exhibition suggests the spectacle of two different cultures meeting in one fantastic city, in which commerce and love of beauty, those great levelers, unite them in a fruitful bond. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Cotter)
 * THE MET: ‘INCISIVE IMAGES: IVORY AND BOXWOOD CARVINGS,’ through Nov. 25. This extraordinary show, drawn almost entirely from the Met’s vaults, presents an array of nearly 100 carved figures, crucifixes, reliefs, containers, hand-held weapons and the occasional piece of furniture. It is an engrossing hive of religious fervor, Classical erudition (and occasional naughtiness), style shifts and multicultural cross-currents. And among the many feats of drop-dead artistic skill are several of traffic-stopping caliber. Don’t miss it. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (See above.) (Smith)
★ THE MET: ‘LOUIS COMFORT TIFFANY AND LAURELTON HALL — AN ARTIST’S COUNTRY ESTATE,’ through May 20. Laurelton Hall may have burned to the ground in 1957, but this exhibition does an excellent job of reassembling what remains of this extraordinary house- museum and its gardens, which Tiffany created for himself in the early 1900s. The Gilded Age opulence of the place, which occupied 580 acres overlooking Long Island Sound, is conveyed most blatantly by the Temple-of-Dendur-size Daffodil Terrace, in wood, marble and glass. The main events are the glass windows, vases and lamps, where Tiffany’s genius for color, love of the exotic and reverence for nature coalesce into an unforgettable mystical materialism. (See above.) (Smith) * THE MET: ‘ONE OF A KIND: THE STUDIO CRAFT MOVEMENT,’ through Sept. 3. Focusing on the postwar development of artist-craftsmen who not only conceive and design their own objects but have a direct hand in making them, this display of furniture, glass, ceramics, metalwork, jewelry and fiber includes funny, quirky, provocative and sometimes gorgeous things. Among its stars are a witty bust by the California funk ceramicist Robert Arneson (1920-92), portraying the mother of the 16th-century painter and printmaker Albrecht Dürer; John Cederquist’s elegant cabinet concealed behind a trompe l’oeil door painted and veneered to look like a battered wooden packing case with a rowdy wave tearing through it; and Bonnie Seeman’s fetching ceramic coffeepot and tray, whose mock cabbage leaves and rhubarb stalks evoke the genteel tradition of 18th-century British and continental china, but can also be read as human rather than vegetative tissue. Traditionalists, too, have their place in this show, with the wood workers Wharton Esherick and Sam Maloof represented by elegantly simple renditions in the furniture line; respectively, a music stand and a Shaker-like settee. (See above.) (Glueck)MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM: ‘APOCALYPSE THEN: MEDIEVAL ILLUMINATIONS FROM THE MORGAN,’ through June 17. Even in the contemporary art world the symbolism of the Book of Revelation, with its demons and lakes of fire, has a subversive appeal. This new exhibition at the Morgan Library celebrates a facsimile of “Las Huelgas Apocalypse” (1220), the largest surviving Spanish illuminated commentary on the Apocalypse. The show, which includes 50 leaves from the original text, unbound and installed around the gallery’s perimeter, offers a walking tour of the medieval imagination. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, morganlibrary.org.
 (Andrea K. Scott)
 ★ EL MUSEO DEL BARRIO: ‘THE DISAPPEARED (LOS DESAPARECIDOS),’ through June 17. The most potent show of contemporary political art of the season, and one of the most moving shows of any kind in the city right now. The title refers to a peculiarly chilling form of violence associated with political upheavals in Latin America over the past 40 years, and now becoming more common in Iraq. 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272, elmuseo .org. (Cotter)
MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: ‘ARTISTIC COLLABORATIONS: 50 YEARS OF UNIVERSAL LIMITED ART EDITIONS,’ through May 21. This exhibition observes the half-century milestone for Universal Limited Art Editions in West Islip, N.Y., and its association with the Museum of Modern Art. The museum has acquired one print from every edition made at Universal, more than 1,200 works by nearly 50 artists. Prints by 12 artists are in this show. Among them are lithographs by Jasper Johns, mostly from the 1960s, with his signature maps and flags. Robert Rauschenberg is represented primarily by lithographs from the 1960s that combine found images of figures like John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson with the freehand scrawling associated with Abstract Expressionism. It’s hard to fault an exhibition that features prints by masters like Mr. Johns and Mr. Rauschenberg and Kiki Smith. But given the somewhat precarious position of prints in the contemporary art world, and with many artists opting to go digital, the inclusion of younger artists would make a good argument that traditional printmaking is still relevant and holds possibilities for this generation. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Martha Schwendener)MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: ‘COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,’ through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea — the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture — should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern’s paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Although it promises work that addresses “perplexing questions,” nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith)
 ★ MOMA: JEFF WALL, through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies mounted on light boxes are enthralling vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can’t stop looking at them. (See above.) (Smith)
★ NATIONAL ACADEMY MUSEUM: HIGH TIMES, HARD TIMES: NEW YORK PAINTING, 1967-1975, through April 22. Organized under the auspices of International Curators Incorporated, this brave if confused exhibition is the first to tackle a neglected subject: New York painting during the period it was supposed to be dead. The show’s 42 works by 37 artists reveal that, far from dead, painting was in fact in an uproar that was commensurate with the artistic, social and political turbulence of the times. The alternation between artists who remained loyal in their way to stretched canvas and those who abandoned it, which makes for clear installation, also tidies up history. The main problem is that the exhibition sticks too purposefully to the margins, mixing generations and levels of achievement and continuing the neglect of the main story. Too much of this work is as derivative now as it was then, and functions more as artifact than art. 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880, nationalacademy.org. (Smith)NEUBERGER MUSEUM OF ART: FUGITIVE ARTIST: THE EARLY WORK OF RICHARD PRINCE, 1974-77, through June 24. Mr. Prince is one of the most elusive, perverse and sardonic of all of the important appropriation artists to emerge in the early 1980s, so perhaps it is not surprising that he has boycotted this exhibition of little-known early work, all from public and private collections. But that doesn’t stop the 50 pieces on view from revealing his roots in 1970s Conceptual Art; his progress from generic to original and radical; or the depth and duration of his fascination with language, photography, printmaking, the more banal forms of urban postwar Americana and a disconnected, decidedly male blankness. If anything, it increases his stature. Purchase College, State University of New York, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, N.Y., (914) 251-6100, neuberger.org. (Smith) ★ NEUE GALERIE: ‘VAN GOGH AND EXPRESSIONISM,’ through July 2. The Neue has, as usual, gathered a stellar roundup of Expressionist art. In one of the show’s most exciting rooms, a third-floor gallery devoted mostly to self-portraits, two extraordinary van Goghs hang at opposite ends: “Self-Portrait With Straw Hat” (1887-88), from the Metropolitan Museum’s collection, filled with energetic, radiating brushstrokes, and the National Gallery’s vibrant self-portrait of the artist holding a palette and brushes, painted about a year later. The most compelling pairing in this room, though, is van Gogh’s “Bedroom” from 1889, the second of three versions he painted of his room in Arles, with Egon Schiele’s obvious homage, “The Artist’s Bedroom in Neulengbach,” painted in 1911, in a darker palette and with a perspective tipped precariously toward the viewer. 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, neuegalerie.org. (Schwendener)NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY: ‘NEW YORK DIVIDED: SLAVERY AND THE CIVIL WAR,’ through Sept. 3. New York has a cosmopolitan pride in itself, but as this exhibition shows, it is not always well deserved. Even after slavery belatedly came to an end in New York State in 1827, New York City was a “hotbed of pro-slavery politics,” inspired by close commercial links with the South and the international cotton trade. For every instance of abolitionist activity, there is another in which slavery is defended or supported. This powerful exhibition, focused on the years between Emancipation and Reconstruction, and featuring documents, videos, audio dramatizations, books, cartoons and historic objects, shows how divided the city was, even during the years of the Civil War. But it also draws attention to the importance of black abolitionists and to the forces that countered slavery’s horrific heritage. It brings to a close the Historical Society’s multiyear exploration of slavery in New York. 170 Central Park West, (212) 873-3400. 
(Edward Rothstein) ONASSIS CULTURAL CENTER: ‘ATHENS-SPARTA,’ through May 12. Painted vases, pottery, sculptured steles, tiny carved figures, writings inscribed on stone and a selection of coins are among the nearly 300 objects in this show, whose first section begins with pieces from both cities during the Geometric Period (1050-700 B.C.). Two other sections deal with the on-again, off-again relationship between the cities in the fifth century B.C., Greece’s glory years, and with the wars they fought: the Persian Wars (about 500 to 449 B.C.) and the Peloponnesian War (431 to 404 B.C.), in which Sparta defeated Athens, only to fade not long after. As society evolved from tribal to civil and felt the first stirrings of democracy during the Archaic Period (650 to 480 B.C.), rigid geometrical motifs were succeeded by more human forms . On view from the sixth century B.C. are two small Attic representations of korai, dressed statues of maidens, said to represent the Athenian aristocracy in rites celebrating the goddess Athena. 645 Fifth Avenue, near 52nd Street, (212) 486-4448. (Glueck)
 P.S. 1 CONTEMPORARY ART CENTER: ‘KATRIN SIGURDARDOTTIR: HIGH PLANE V,’ through May 7. Cut into a space between two levels of P.S. 1 is the Icelandic artist Katrin Sigurdardottir’s “High Plane V,” a miniature artificial landscape of glacial mountains arranged in a naturalistic, faux-snow-covered setting against a painted white background. Visitors climb ladders and peer into one of two holes in the ceiling to view the work. The installation works best when two people mount the ladders and poke their heads in at the same time: then they can both see a disembodied head floating in the middle of the icy landscape. 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, ps1.org. (Genocchio) ★ UKRAINIAN MUSEUM: ‘CROSSROADS: MODERNISM IN UKRAINE, 1910-1930,’ through April 29. Some of the great names in Modernist Russian art — Malevich, El Lissitsky, Rodchenko, Archipenko and Exter — were actually born, or identified themselves as, Ukrainian. And this show of more than 70 works by 21 artists, including many interesting lesser-knowns, informs us that their Ukrainian-ness made an impact on their contributions to the Modernist movements of the 20th century. Discoveries in the show include Vsevolod Maksymovych, a painter drawing on Symbolist sources, heavily influenced by classical themes and the campy erotica of the British graphic artist Aubrey Beardsley; and Anatol Petrytsky, a painter and creator of lighthearted, collagelike sketches for classical and avant-garde opera and ballet. Stressing as it does the importance of Ukrainian participation in Modernist art, the show is equally significant in its exposure to Americans of lively talents, largely unknown. 222 East Sixth Street, East Village, (212) 228-0110, ukrainianmuseum.org. (Glueck) WADSWORTH ATHENEUM MUSEUM OF ART: ‘FAITH AND FORTUNE: FIVE CENTURIES OF EUROPEAN MASTERWORKS,’ through Dec. 9. One of the most appealing things about this gathering of some 400 treasures is the mix, with knockout paintings keeping company with small sculptures, elaborate table furnishings, decorative platters, Meissen knockoffs of Chinese pottery, a porcelain birdcage and vases and such. Strolling through the galleries, you’ll find treasures like “Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy” (about 1594-95), said to be the first authentic Caravaggio in an American museum; Fra Angelico’s poignant, poetic fragment “Head of an Angel” (about 1455-50); and Francisco de Zurbarán’s fearsome portrayal of a dead martyr, “Saint Serapion” (1628). But the pièce de résistance is an entire gallery made into an art and curio cabinet, with a planned clutter of brilliant objects that play to a viewer’s inner acquisitor: exotic shells mounted in gold; an extraordinary Baroque ivory carving (presumed to be before 1650) of Adam and Eve; an automatic tabletop clock (about 1619) with a standing lion that could roll its eyes, open its jaws and stick out its tongue when the hours struck. Dazzlement prevails. 600 Main Street, Hartford, (860) 278-2670, wadsworthatheneum.org. (Glueck)
WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: ‘GORDON MATTA-CLARK RETROSPECTIVE,’ through June 3. I have no doubt that Matta-Clark is now being turned into a hot commodity, but at least at the Whitney you can see what he aspired to be. At the center of the exhibition is “Splitting.” To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The drawings are casual and not too interesting, but the luxurious black-and-white photographs from Paris speak more to Matta-Clark’s formal elegance. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Kimmelman) ★ WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: ‘LORNA SIMPSON,’ through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson’s career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as “identity art,” but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (See above.) (Cotter)
Galleries: Chelsea
★ ‘PAINTINGS, FLAGS & IRON: HAITIAN ART FROM THE LAST FIFTY YEARS’ This splendid exhibition offers total immersion in the originality and continued vitality of Haiti’s self-taught artists. Works by well-known painters like Hector Hyppolite, Toussaint Auguste and Rigaud Benoit range across religion, history and everyday themes. They include still lifes, landscapes and Pierre Joseph Valcin’s enthralling rendering of a maternity ward. The forged and welded sculptures of Georges Liautaud and Gabriel Bien-Aimé are on a par with Bill Traylor’s antic silhouette drawings. And there are no words for the extravagantly sequined and beaded flags depicting Voodoo spirits and saints, except fabulous. Edward Thorp Gallery, 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street, (212) 691-6565, edwardthorpgallery.com, through April 21. (Smith)
 ★ LAMAR PETERSON Best known for his fanciful, Pop-inflected paintings of African-American suburban life, this young painter smashes that subject to smithereens in his new work, a promising advancement that is already yielding rewards. Fredericks & Freiser, 536 West 24th Street, (212) 633-6555, fredericksfreisergallery.com, through April 28. (Cotter)
Galleries: Other
‘GIFTS OF THE FOREST: NATIVE TRADITIONS IN WOOD AND BARK’ Drawn from the collections of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center in Connecticut, this show celebrates the trees of the rich forests that once covered the Northeast, yielding essential materials to the Pequot and other Eastern Woodland cultures. The objects run from ancient woodworking tools to contemporary objects that carry on tribal traditions, like the simple and beautiful wooden flute made in 1999 by Hawk Henires (Nipmuc) and adorned with an elegantly carved bird motif. Many things here were made in the 19th and 20th centuries: handsome woven baskets, carved bowls and spoons, decorated cradle boards for carrying babies, birch bark canoe models, an elegant birch-bark hamper whose sides bear a stylized tree motif. UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52nd Streets, (212) 713-2885, through April 27. (Glueck) 
★ ‘THOMAS STRUTH: MAKING TIME’ Through the 1990s, the German photographer Thomas Struth became an art world celebrity for his outsize, absorbing portraits of crowds interacting with artwork in the world’s great museums. As a follow-up, he is presenting the American premiere of two new series of pictures of audiences beholding single masterpieces in the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid, and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. The show, which cannily allows us to look safely at others looking at art, is one of the most visually sumptuous and thought-probing in the city. Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160, mariangoodman.com, through April 28. (Genocchio)
Last Chance
 ★ KRISTIN BAKER: SURGE AND SHADOW In these clever, ambitious mergers of Pop, Minimalism and Abstract Expressionism, abstract painting takes another turn for the spectacular, aided by the freshly white-on-white Deitch space. Cataclysmic compositions and an all-plastic, labor-intensive process strike the eye with a dazzling newness, but the eye adjusts and is eventually bored. A series of smaller studies evades the prescribed soullessness. Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, near Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300; closes tomorrow. (Smith)
 ★ ‘EARLY CHINESE BUDDHIST SCULPTURE,’ Asia Week is over, but its essence lingers on in this exhibition of beautiful carved stone figures of Buddhas and bodhisattvas dating from the Northern Wei to Tang periods in China. This is the type of work that elicited rapturous responses when shown in London and Washington a few seasons back. Throckmorton Fine Art, 145 East 57th Street, third floor, (212) 223-1059; closes tomorrow. 
(Cotter)
GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: ‘FAMILY PICTURES’ This show sounds ripe with possibilities. The results, however, are more mixed. The exhibition is drawn from the museum’s collection, which explains some of its exclusions and limitations. Many artists you associate with contemporary photography and the family are not in attendance: Richard Bellingham, Tina Barney, Malerie Marder. There is also a sense of false advertising in the exhibition’s title. The museum’s news release extends the exhibition’s exploration into “representation of families and children in contemporary art and video.” Images of children, you quickly realize, can operate as a completely different genre. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org; closes on Monday. (Schwendener) 
 * ANYA KIELAR: ‘LADY’ The traditions of photomontage, collage and assemblage are sliced, diced and reconfigured here with surgical precision, feminist wit and a terrific sense of light, dark and color. The works range from two to three dimensions, with the best — mysterious boxed collages that cross Hannah Hoch with Kembra Phaler — landing squarely in between. Daniel Reich Gallery, 537A West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-4949, danielreichgallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith)
★ MOMA: ARMANDO REVERÓN  Unless you spotted his single smoke-puff of a painting at MoMA months ago, Armando Reverón probably means nothing to you. Why should he? The artist, who died in 1954, spent most of his life in a shack by the sea in his native Venezuela. Many of his contemporaries dismissed him as nuts. His white-on-white pictures are practically unphotographable. But chances are that if you visit this retrospective, you’ll find yourself thinking about him a lot. His art and his story are like few others, and so is the museum’s inspired installation: a single, long corridor with cabinetlike rooms of paintings on either side and, at the very end, against a sea-green wall, a life-size doll with giant bat wings floating overhead. (212) 708-9400, moma.org; closes on Monday. (Cotter) WILHELM SASNAL A truncated, slightly altered version of a Polish film from the 1960s provides the frame or caption for often drab, studiously incomplete paintings that reciprocate with hints of cinematic light or depictions of movie screens. A genuine sense of postwar Communist bloc deprivation is evoked, without giving the viewer much to work with. Anton Kern Gallery, 532 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 367-9663, antonkerngallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith)
 *
‘DAVID SHAPIRO: ROCK IRAQ,’ A while back, David Shapiro filled a gallery with the empty containers of all the consumer products he had bought and used over two years. His current Pierogi solo takes up less space: it’s an 8-by-8-foot tabletop model of an imaginary benefit concert. The exact cause espoused isn’t stated. But with no musicians present, and corporate logos plastering the concert hall walls, emptiness and waste are the unmistakable themes. Pierogi, 177 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-2144, pierogi2000.com; closes on Monday. (Cotter)

Talk to the Newsroom:
Style Editor Trip Gabriel
2007-02-12T15:17:00.000Z
Trip Gabriel, The Times's style editor, answered questions from readers in February 2007. Following are the questions and his answers.
Mr. Gabriel oversees the Sunday Styles and Thursday Styles sections, as well as fashion coverage in the daily paper. He is a former reporter in the Style department. Before coming to The Times in 1994, he was a contributing editor of Rolling Stone and a frequent contributor to The Times Magazine and other publications. 
Several other editors have answered questions in this column, including Executive Editor Bill Keller, Science Editor Laura Chang, Sports Editor Tom Jolly and Obituaries Editor Bill McDonald. Their responses and those of other Times editors are on the Talk to the Newsroom page.
These discussions will continue in future weeks with other Times editors.
Is Style Only for the Upper Class?
Q. While I always look at the section with interest, I sometimes can't shake the feeling that Style is defined by any two of a writer's friends with too much money and time on their hands. The "A Night Out With..." pieces, for instance, often suggest nightspots that most people couldn't poke their noses in if they didn't know the right people. Even some of the bylines of those articles reek of highfalutin-ness; how am I supposed to take an article seriously when it's written "By Zo"? I don't get the sense from your section that anyone who lives paycheck to paycheck has Style. Does "Style," by definition, percolate downward from the upper class? And can it be affordable?
-- John Dillon, New Haven 
A. Thank you for your question. This is the kind of thing we talk about regularly in our department. Indeed, it can sometimes seem that the accoutrements of the stylish life --­ fashion, entertainment, destinations --­ as presented in Thursday Styles and Sunday Styles are expensive. Fortunately, there are many exceptions. A few quick examples: a Pulse column on Valentine’s Day cards from $3; a Dress Codes column last week on stylish white, men’s sneakers included a pair for $40; and a Skin Deep column about the “cosmetics restriction diet” reported that all your skin really needs is a few products from the drug store under $30.
The bigger point, to me, is that what we call our Styles coverage is really not about stuff. It’s not primarily about getting and spending. It’s about people and their behavior, and I imagine I’ll have more to say about that as this conversation unfolds.
By the way, I think you may overestimate the exclusivity of New York night spots. I did a spot check of the past half dozen “Night Out With...’’ columns, and I’m sure you can get a reservation at any of the restaurants mentioned without knowing anyone. And not all of the places are expensive. The writers of “Aqua Teen Hunger Force’’ spent their night out at Daddy D’z BBQ in Atlanta. (Motto: “We ain’t pretty, but we’re good.’’)
As for a writer named Zo, you’ve created a great mystery in my department; no one can recall making such an assignment. Be assured that all our writers are real people, not pseudonyms, and none of them are particularly highfalutin.
Mystery solved: The byline on the article you mentioned appeared in the newspaper as Zoe (with two dots, or diaresis, on the E) Wolff, but our archives on the Web site cut off the byline because it was unable to "read" the character with the diaresis. Our Web site staff has fixed the problem. Thanks for the heads up.
To Pleat or Not to Pleat?
Q. Can't seem to get a read on if pleats on men's trousers are back, never left, or have been banished for all time. Not talking about the multipleat 1980 style Zoot suit type, just the basic pleats. I'm a slender 6-foot guy, and was brought up reading that as such, you wanted pleats. Now I hear conflicting info from clothing salesmen.
 
-- Josh Taylor
A. Oh dear, I’m afraid it’s going to be a tough week if there are many questions like this. Though I oversee sections with “Styles” in the title, I am no authority on how to dress. Fortunately there are people on the fashion staff in my department who really know their stuff. I relayed your question to Eric Wilson, a fashion reporter, and here is what he said:
“Unlike women, men have traditionally been slow to adapt to new styles. It took a decade for flat-front pants, originally shown in the collections of Helmut Lang, Calvin Klein and Miuccia Prada in the early 1990's, to catch on in the mainstream. Now they are the norm at retailers from Eddie Bauer to J.Crew. As store clerks will tell you, flat-front pants make most men look slimmer and taller.
“But pleats have been eradicated from fashion for long enough now that some designers are beginning to experiment with them again. Stefano Pilati, the designer for Yves Saint Laurent, has been showing them since fall 2005, and now we see little pleats or big reverse pleats at other influential men’s collections like Dior Homme, Cloak and Michael Bastian. Both styles look good now, although pleats generally favor the tall and lean. Justin Timberlake, for example, has been wearing tweedy YSL three-piece suits with pleated pants in his concert appearances. So you could say they are coming back, but I’d give it another few years before pleated pants again become commonplace.’’
Why Are There So Many Ads?
Q. My big complaint is that the section looks like it’s created just for advertisers and society people, not for general readers. I don’t think your latest section in Sunday’s Times had much more than 50 percent editorial. There are already many magazines out there where you can’t find the editorial amid all the ads, why do readers have to see this in your newspaper?
-- Bill Fischer, Annandale, Va.
A. We run about the same number of columns of news each week; the ads expand or contract depending on the season, the strength of the economy and the budgets of marketers. I share your impression that the ads sometimes seem to compete with the editorial content, but look at this way: without ads we wouldn’t be able to report, edit and publish the articles in Styles, or any other department of the paper.
Styles and Trends on the Street
Q: I like Bill Cunningham’s photographs, but sometimes they seem to promote certain products; for example in a recent photo essay on shiny bags, most of the women carry one brand. This does not suggest a style, but a trend, and an expensive one at that. Do you at the Times get products for exposure such as this?
A. Unlike reporters and critics who interpret fashion directions from the runways, Bill Cunningham, The Times’s resident genius of street fashion photography, documents what people actually wear (and carry). With his camera, he seems to connect the dots before anyone else. If the streets are a parade of women in bulky sweaters with wide leather belts, or there is an outbreak of head-to-toe winter white or every other woman on Madison Avenue seems to be carrying a silver or gold handbag, you can be sure it’s Bill’s eye that has made the connection. It’s never the case that a trend or product was suggested to us by a company.
Are There Fees for Wedding Announcements?
Q. Does The Times charge a fee to get a wedding announcement listed? How about the highlighted wedding?
A. No, no fees are charged for announcements in the Weddings & Celebrations pages, or for the Vows column that features one couple’s story. There is a link on the Web page for Weddings & Celebrations explaining how to submit an announcement, or you can call a recorded message at (212) 556-7689. The information is supplied by couples and verified by Times reporters. Coming soon: videos shot by couples about how they met, to appear with their announcement on the Web. Look for details about submitting videos on the Weddings & Celebrations page this Wednesday,­ Valentine’s Day, of course.
Navigating the Styles Path 
Q. I would like to compliment you on having such great writers contributing to the Styles sections. I particularly appreciate Guy Trebay and Cathy Horyn; both combine wonderful prose with insightful commentary about the culture of our times. I always read the last paragraph of a Guy Trebay article in order to learn his latest “post-modern” take on culture, politics and power. Horyn’s thoughts on the relationship between fashion and culture are much appreciated.
My question for you as editor of these sections is: How do you navigate among issues such as objectivity in reporting, subject matter and appropriateness for the Styles sections, and some of your writers’ penchants for political and social commentary? About a year ago it occurred to me that the Styles Sections were out ahead of the rest of The Times in their critique of American politics, culture and social life. I suppose this makes sense since we are living in a society and time dominated by the industries of culture and style. But, that is hardly the conventional/historical tradition of the sections as a repository for fashion fluff and the doings of New York’s social elite, subjects once thought to be close to the heart of the “woman of the house.”
-- E. Taylor
A. That’s a lot to chew on. I think you’ve placed your finger on how Cathy Horyn and Guy Trebay have transformed the job of fashion critic and reporter into that of cultural critic; they see beyond, around and through clothes. That is, in part, why they have followings among many readers who aren’t just trying to pick out a wardrobe. (When Cathy or Guy writes as a critic, rather than a reporter, we label those articles “Fashion Review” or “Fashion Diary.’’)
In determining what’s appropriate for the Styles sections, I have a rule of thumb: If people are talking about it at cocktail parties or around the dinner table, we want to find an angle. This is how I see the evolution of the two Styles sections from the days you refer to when Style news was “women’s news.’’ In fact, the paper used to have a page in the 1960's called “Food, Family, Fashion, Furnishings,’’ also known as the four F’s, to which many people might have added a fifth F, for “fluff.’’
But nowadays Styles looks at how we live our lives ­-- all kinds of social trends, raising children, relationships, how we experience new technologies and even the occasional exegesis of the trucker hat or kaffiyeh. Which may tell us something about geo-politics, or at the very least when a trend is best left alone.
What Makes a Styles Story?
Q. You’re doing a fascinating job with the section ... is there a thought-through "mix" for your pieces? Is it gut? And what makes a piece pop ... or resonate? Keep rocking. You’re getting it done in a way that’s both smart and utterly current! Bravo.
-- Holly Gleason, Nashville
A. Just so readers know, Ms. Gleason and I aren't related, and she doesn’t owe me any money. We've never met.
The Styles sections are a bit like magazines in the sense that the mix of stories, especially on the cover, is all important. And because there is little hard news on our beat -- ­ no Style press conferences to cover --­ the gut instincts of editors and reporters about what to include is crucial. Reporters require a strong spirit of enterprise. The reward is that when they hit the target, or a piece "pops," people talk about it. Ask Warren St. John, who identified the metrosexual in Styles in 2003. Or Guy Trebay, who profiled real-life gay cowboys in Wyoming in 2005 when “Brokeback Mountain’’ was released.
Dressing for Success Just Out of College
Q. I am a recent college grad and would love to develop a business style to help me climb the corporate ladder. Toward that end I’ve been studying how successful men dress. There’s this guy -- a wildly eccentric Tuscan man, famed for strutting around Manhattan in $10,000 Italian suits while hobnobbing with billionaires who nosh in his restaurant at noontime. He also dons Lucchese cowboy boots almost every day. Is this the kind of style I can adopt and make my own?
-- Quint Jibril, Pelham, N.Y.
A. All right, back to Eric Wilson for specific fashion advice:
“Manhattan is full of Italian restaurants managed by men who are both eccentrically and impeccably dressed. Walking into their restaurants, a patron should know right away to whom he or she should genuflect.
“As to the broader issue of developing a style for business, that all depends on your business, not to mention your personal threshold for being teased for wearing cowboy boots. Since you are starting out, a $10,000 suit strikes me as a less sensible investment than more basic styles that can be put together for under $500 at H&M and easily replaced if they turn out to be fashion flops. Remember that looking like you spent too much on your clothes can also be a hindrance on the corporate ladder. Conversely, always splurge on a good pair of shoes. A $500 pair of Prada loafers will outlast any five pairs of $100 shoes.’’
Announcements of Same-Sex Unions
Q. Hello from a faithful reader in the Midwest. I'm delighted that the Styles section includes same-sex unions in the wedding lists. Fantastic! What kinds of responses have you gotten to this over the past few years? I haven't yet seen one of the more in-depth articles about how couples met and how their relationship developed with a focus on a gay or lesbian couple, though. It's very encouraging to those of us in less cosmopolitan (and less diverse) communities. I read through the list of weddings and celebrations every week in hopes of seeing more same-sex couples, as a way to find some hope as a single lesbian in the so-called "heartland."
-- Phoebe Nielsen 
A. At the time we printed the first same-sex announcement in 2002 (and changed the name of the pages from "Weddings" to "Weddings/Celebrations"), we received several dozen letters, almost all positive. Frankly, from the strenuous internal discussions that preceded the change, I expected there would be protesters on 43rd Street, but in the end there was almost no controversy. We rarely hear comments these days, pro or con. Our readers seem to accept the formalizing of same-sex unions as part of modern life.
As for including gay and lesbian couples in the longer Vows column, there have been several, among them the musician Janis Ian and Patricia Snyder, who married in Canada; and the playwright Tony Kushner and Mark Harris, an editor, who had a commitment ceremony in New York. In 2005 the column described the wedding in Massachusetts of Carl Stanley McGee, a lawyer from Alabama, whose family was less upset that he was marrying a man, John Huston Finley IV, than a Democrat.
Inner Workings of "Weddings/Celebrations"
Q. Something I've always been curious about how wedding announcements are chosen? What's the ratio of submissions to those printed? In addition, how do you select the wedding that is highlighted each Sunday?
-- Patrick L. Eleey
Q. Do you prohibit pictures of the couple dressed more formally than what we know as business casual and pictures of the bride alone? So few of your published shots have the subjects in tailored clothing, jackets/ties, dresses or dressy sportswear for women. I recognize that you have banished pre-staged wedding dress shots.
-- J Gettinger, New York, NY.
A. For the answers to these questions about the internal workings of "Weddings/Celebrations," I turn to Robert Woletz, our society editor, who over 10 years has greatly expanded the cultural, ethnic and geographic range of couples included. Here's what Bob says:
"We make selections primarily based on the couple's achievements, and we're always on the lookout for couples with entertaining stories about their courtships. We have space to publish only a small handful of the submissions, which rise and fall with the seasons. In May, June and September, we may receive 300 to 400 a week and only have room for about one in 10."
"As for the photos, a decade ago The Times published formal photos exclusively. The policy changed when couples, and some of their photographers, expressed a desire to submit images of brides and bridegrooms in less formal settings and clothing. While we would gladly publish photos of brides in their gowns or couples in formal wear, it is now rare that they submit them."
A Gay Focus in Styles?
Q. Once upon a time, the lifestyle sections of a newspaper were called the "women’s pages." Now, of course, we know the sections are for everyone. Still, with some snark, Gawker.com and others sometimes call the section “Thursgay Styles,” implying the section is for gay men or perhaps women and gay men. How do you feel about this diminutive nickname for your section?
-- Chris Phillips, Brooklyn
A. An interesting question. As far as “Thursgay Styles,’’ it strikes me as kind of retro that a blog presenting itself as cutting edge about media and celebrity gossip would equate an interest in men’s fashion with being gay. Wasn’t that your grandfather’s thing? Thursday Styles includes a small amount of men’s fashion, mainly an every-three-weeks column, Dress Codes, but we are much more likely to cover aspects of gay life in Sunday Styles.
On the broader topic, there is no question that a lot of the influence in the style world originates with gay men. Have you noticed that straight male hipsters this winter have bushy beards and long, stringy hair, like George Harrison, circa “The Concert for Bangladesh”? It’s a look that comes in no small part from the subculture of gay men known as bears, who affect lumberjack whiskers and plaid shirts. Which is a reaction to the clean-shaven, waxed and moisturized look for men. And that leads right to the next question …
Q. A while back there was the famous Sunday Styles article about the coming out of the "metrosexual." That article seemed to cause a lot of grief. I remember one other article that seemed to push the phrase "gay vague" into the lexicon, and I’m wondering where these articles are coming from, if there is an internal debate, have there been any regrets, and what’s the need for these kind of labels around gayness and straight men?
A. Our piece on metrosexuals, which didn’t coin the term but pushed it into the spotlight, appeared a month before the launch of “Queer Eye for the Straight Guy’’ in 2003; the other story you refer to, from 2005, noted that many men, gay and straight, “have migrated to a middle ground where the cues traditionally used to pigeonhole sexual orientation ­-- hair, clothing, voice, body language --­ are more and more ambiguous.’’
Even though both articles had long shelf lives in the public consciousness, and in some ways were controversial, the only debates we had over publishing them were the same as with every trend story: Is there enough evidence to support the story? Is it balanced and thoroughly reported? How in heck can we get great art to go with it?
Sunday Styles has no overarching thesis or agenda about gayness or straightness, but it’s clear the issues around sexual orientation in our society are evolving very rapidly, and often play out in the worlds of style. So we cover them.
The Wall Between Editorial and News
Q. Although I recognize that there is a strong wall between editorial and the newsroom at The Times, the disconnect with regard to the Styles sections is staggering. The Times editorial stance is certainly liberal, as shown by its pursuit of social justice, opposition to tax cuts and the regular editorials decrying greed on Wall Street. On the other hand, the Styles sections are healthily laced with reviews of $10,000 handbags, articles about couture houses and long pieces about the pleasures of private jet ownership. Do you not consider that the Styles sections’ (generally slavishly approving) coverage of these subjects is merely feeding (and creating) the wealth obsession that the Times editorials are regularly decrying? Furthermore, does the Times’ income from luxury advertising associated with Styles sections undermine the righteousness of its editorial stance?
-- Andrew S., New York
A. You’re right, there is a wall between the editorial department and the newsroom, so I have no answer to your larger philosophical question; we’re not asked to consider if our coverage supports or contradicts positions of the editorial page, nor, I suspect you agree, should we.
But I’m going to take strong exception to the premise underlying your question, that the Styles sections offer “generally slavish approval’’ of luxury goods, designer clothes and a plutocrat lifestyle. First of all, that would be news to the fashion designers who regularly ban our critics from runway shows after an unfavorable review. The last time we wrote at length about expensive handbags it was to report that the most expensive ones, $650 and up, were selling strongly ­-- that’s news, objectively delivered ­-- and the story didn’t gush over the bags, it raised a skeptical eyebrow, noting, “In their pursuit of the season's most coveted bags, many are giving common sense the slip.”
Look at today’s Thursday Styles section: A cover story examines laws aimed at regulating chemicals in makeup. The Critical Shopper columnist visits a vintage dress store where she buys a $185 dress. A Gear Test of scales that measure body fat finds the best one is also the cheapest, $34.98 from Sam’s Club.
So give us a break. It’s a bum rap that we fawn over the rich or equate being “stylish” with the consumption of luxury goods that are out of reach of most people. If anything, the tone of these sections is irreverent when looking at the lifestyles of the wealthy -- just as it is when looking at bohemians, artists, celebrities and others whose tastes often filter down, or up, to shape mass taste in America.
Style on Limited Budget and Time?
Q. Focusing for the moment on the part of the Styles sections that are about buying things, the question is not whether some of the things that are recommended could be affordable to people other than the very rich. The question is whether people who don't have that much free time to shop, and don't make much money (the vast majority of Americans) can have style in the ensembles that they wear, and if so, how. A single $40 pair of sneakers does not make someone have style, and neither does a $600 pair of sneakers. The real question that John Dillon is asking is, taking the average person's salary and rent in New York, after taxes and food and transportation and entertainment, how much is it reasonable for someone to spend on clothing (and tailoring) in a year?
Another way to ask the question is: The vast majority of people pictured in your sections have tailored clothes. Do you think the majority of New Yorkers can afford tailored clothes? If not, what can they do so as to have style? Does it require a long-term plan of using your disposable income in the right places? Is it smarter to shop at more expensive stores that have a wider range of sizes, or at cheaper stores, followed by some relatively inexpensive tailoring? How can a person on a modest salary with limited spare time accomplish this feat? I am not being facetious -- I actually would be interested in seeing how one would allocate one's time in order to do it. I think that your section would increase in readership significantly if it spoke to this problem, which is a prerequisite to "style."
-- Benjamin Galynker, Brooklyn
A. I take your point, and it's a good one. As I think I've established, I am no authority on how to dress well, so I can't immediately say how one acquires a sense of style on a budget and with limited time (and Mr. Wilson is out of the office on assignment). But you raise interesting issues we should think about for future coverage. Please stay tuned.
Looking High and Low
Q. Looking at the style/economic class argument that seems to be unfolding, I feel people are talking about it in the wrong order. Of course the Styles sections focus on the interests and behaviors of wealthy people, but that's not to be interpreted as "the rich have better taste." Rather, they are the ones with the expendable income and free time necessary to lavish large quantities of time and energy on the enterprise, and they tend to be the first to develop highly specific, interesting and unusual tastes. Most people are too busy to keep abreast of the latest fashion developments. Isn't this what the Styles sections aim to cover -- the most recent and unexpected events in a field that is largely superfluous (though still very interesting)? The entire section is not an editorial, and should not be asked to take a moral stance on the issue.  
-- Nan Wakefield, Austin, Texas
A. That the sort-of-idle rich are style leaders because they can devote themselves to cultivating their tastes is an interesting view, though I don't really agree with you. Our reporting on so-called high society in the past couple of year has pointed out that whereas designers, like Bill Blass, once looked to the tastes of Park Avenue dames for inspiration, nowadays many younger socialites (and Hollywood stars) are given their finery by designers who are looking to exploit them as walking billboards.
Original and influential style comes from everywhere, high and low, rich and poor, young and old. Think of hip hop street fashion, or the blue-collar Carhartt guy look still popular in Williamsburg, or the Factory-era Edie Sedgwick, whose style is being revived. We aim to cover all of it.
Getting Paid
Q.  Isn't youth style more than somewhat exploitative in that urban (read: black) styles set American, then international trends, with no payoffs to the black originators?  
-- Arnie Tracey
A.  Ask Russell Simmons (who founded the Phat Farm clothing brand), Sean Combs (Sean John), Damon Dash (Rocawear) or Pharrell Williams (Billionaire Boys Club) about getting paid.

Q. I love wearing mini jean skirts summer or winter. Even though I see a lot of women wearing them during the summer, I don’t see many wearing them during the winter. Is it a fashion faux pas to wear jean mini skirts during the winter? Is age an issue when wearing jean mini skirts?
>-- Betty
A. A very stylish member of our fashion staff, who is shy about seeing her name in print, offers this advice: “Weather permitting, denim miniskirts are a perfectly appropriate look for winter. Pull on some opaque tights (I favor Wofford cotton velvet), a pair of chunky boots and, say, a cropped jacket or bulky sweater, and you’re good to go. As for age being an issue when wearing denim, bite your tongue.’’

Q. Is there a way to get to a fashion show without being a model or a designer and having no connections.
-- Albina
A. I’m afraid that’s a tough ticket to get. Fashion Week in New York is a trade event, meaning you have to be invited by the designers (or really by their publicity arms), and only press, store buyers and “special guests’’ like socialite customers and celebrities are generally included. The best way for a civilian to see a show is to have a friend in the business who can get you a seat. Fashion students are often allowed to wait for standing-room admission. Or why not start a fashion blog and register next season as a member of the press. See the Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Web site for registration information.
Following Leaders or Followers?
Q. As a former New York fashion designer who was paid to predict "style" months in advance, I often feel your Styles sections trail after followers, not leaders. New fashion trends rarely start on couture runways. They start in the streets, on the backs of art students who wouldn’t be caught dead toting a plastic handbag that costs more than their rent (even if they could afford it). Why celebrate the insecurity of Fifth Avenue’s fashion sheep -- when there’s so much creativity and excitement riding the A train?
-- Stacia Friedman
A. Yesterday’s Thursday Styles looked at the thrift store fashions that models show up in backstage, which often influence designers and street trends. A story not long ago on “the Retro Kids,’’ eight friends from Brooklyn and Queens, described their obsession with 80's hip hop looks. The “Life as a Runway’’ photo feature about every two weeks documents the unexpected (but not unstudied) dress codes one finds at a poetry reading, an Atlantic City casino, a museum dance party, etc. We ride the A train, and the N, G and F.
 
Not Everyone's Cup of Tea
Q. I’ve been reading The Times --­ America’s Newspaper of Record --­ for 40 years. The Sunday Styles section is obscene to me and I suspect other readers. If I wanted a copy of People or Us, I’d pick one up. If you spent the money covering the news of the world better, we’d be better off as a people.
-- Ross Salinger
A. I’m sorry you feel that way. The wonderful thing about a newspaper as broad as The Times is there’s something for almost everyone. If we lost the subscriptions of people who love the Styles sections, not to mention the ads the sections attract, there would be less money to cover the kind of news you prefer. This realization was made in the 1970’s (not long after you started reading the paper), when my predecessors in the Style department created sections like Weekend and House & Home. They saved the newspaper financially at the time, and though the news in our feature sections is typically labeled "soft,'' the reporting and thinking are not. I’m sure we will move into the future with our readers, inventing new areas of coverage as it becomes evident, while remaining completely faithful to the journalistic standards The Times stands for.
Door Policies and Discrimination
Q. You frequently report on the restrictive door policies of clubs. Although licensed by the state to serve liquor to everyone, they decide, usually by a combination of dress and looks, who gets in and who does not. The discriminatory ramifications of that policy are so obvious that I wonder if you are troubled by reporting them.
--­ Howard Burkat
A. One of the things I really like about our “Boite” column in Sunday Styles, which covers night clubs, is the sidebar spelling out the unspoken dress code, and other tips for besting the doorman at his game.
Is Gay News Ghettoized?
Q. I never got a response to the e-mail below, sent back in 2005. It appears, unfortuantely, that little has changed since then, so maybe you’ll do your readers a favor and attempt a reply this week:
"This message comes to you from an avid fan and daily reader of The New York Times online edition. In recent weeks, I have noticed a disturbing trend in the positioning of articles in The New York Times. On July 17, you ran an interesting and timely story by Alex Williams about a gay teenager’s struggle with attending a camp where he would be “straightened out.’’ Why did this story, involving family legal rights and the psychology of homosexuality, appear only in the Styles section? That section is generally the home of stories like today’s: lip gloss, cosmetic surgery and dress shops. The answer, I fear, is a troubling one: gay news belongs in the dress-shop section of the paper, because gays simply adore fashion, jewelry and other shiny things.
"I hope The New York Times understands that most gay men are far more interested in political issues and cultural affairs than in lip gloss. Before you continue down this slippery slope, please check your sexual prejudices. Even when accompanied by slick graphics and interactive media, bigotry isn’t pretty.''
--­ Marc Lallanilla
A. Let me apologize for not replying in 2005. The issue you discuss occasionally comes up when we run certain kinds of stories in Sunday Styles, not only on gay rights but also politics. (A piece last year asking if America is ready to elect a woman president got a lot of angry mail, not because of the story but because it ran in Sunday Styles --­ and because it was illustrated with a pink handbag with a presidential seal.) The perception that "serious'' news is being ghettoized in the Styles sections is even stronger with some readers on the Web, where our stories run under the heading “Fashion & Style.’’
To set your mind at ease, there is no top-down directive to include such articles in the Styles sections; they run here because we editors in the department liked them and assigned them and thought they would benefit from the longer, more magazinelike treatment we can give them. Mostly they appear in Sunday Styles because we define style so broadly, which I’ve tried to explain in this conversation. “Styles’’ is not just lip gloss and dress shops; it is how we live our lives today, including new perspectives on dating and mating (see the “Modern Love’’ column), workplace trends, the culture of online behavior, parenting, socializing (and social climbing!), changing attitudes about the roles of men and women and, yes, changing attitudes about sexual orientation. Because our country's accommodation of its gay minority is unfolding so quickly, in ways that are as much social as political, we look at the subject regularly. The July 2005 story you referred to seemed right for Styles in part because the teenager sent to a "re-education" camp posted a diary of his ordeal on a new social networking site few had heard of, called MySpace.
And now, I feel the need for an easy one…
Q. What are the spring colors this year?
A. Silver, gold, hot pink, yellow and orange. You read it here first.
